results.notes:
Cap: 11 cm wide, round, flat with broad umbo slightly darker in color than overall cap, surface dry with several pale patches, light gray with radial brown overtones, paler at margin, flesh white, odor potato-like.

Gills: nearly free, crowded, white, numerous lamellulae.

Stalk: 18 cm long, 1.6 cm thick, tapering to apex, white, solid, somewhat floccose, ring light gray, superior, pendant, bulb subglobose, 4.5 cm wide.

Spore Print: white.

Spores: 6-8 µm, globose, smooth, hyaline.

Fruiting: solitary, terrestrial, in beech and oak woods.

Comments: Not sure if this is A. brunnescens as no part of this specimen stained red or brown. Cap color in my pics seem to be more green than in reality. Sorry. Please see actual cap color description above.

results.notes:
John Plischke III identified this as bicolor when we found it in the same locations at a walk last year. Discussion ensued because I swear it is not the same mushroom we find in Allegheny County and call by the same name (e.g., observation 243105). These are a typical bolete when it comes to texture, odor, taste, and heft. The Allegheny County ones are unusually dense and heavy by comparison, with much meatier and more significant stipe flesh.

Found in grass and moss on a lawn scattered with oaks and maples. The weather has been dry and the water table is low, but recent rain left this area soft underfoot. Some lower parts (not here) were boggy.

Mycelium was white. The red on the cap and stipe appears to have been a pure, dark red at one point but has aged to include a lot more tan and grow more cracked. Stipe is almost entirely red over a yellow base color. No reticulation. I’ve noticed that the stipe on Pine Ridge specimens is (almost) always an even pillar and relatively thin compared to the Allegheny version, which is often clavate, has more yellow in the skin, and is wider compared to the diameter of the cap. Memory says the Allegheny version is also a clearer and brighter yellow.

Cap flesh was pale yellow, but past the point where you might wonder if it ought to be called white. Larval tunnels were dark red.

Thin pore layer was yellow, bruised blue/black, maintained the dark color (shifted to brown/black) several hours later.

Ammonia on Cap Skin: No strong reaction.
Ammonia on Stipe Skin: No strong reaction.
Ammonia on Pores: No reaction, or possibly a little darker yellow.
Ammonia on Cap Context: No reaction.
Ammonia on Stipe Context: No reaction.

KOH on Cap Skin: Orange. (Baorangia bicolor is supposed to have no reaction).
KOH on Stipe Skin: Faint yellow orange.
KOH on Pores: Obvious red/orange.
KOH on Cap Context: Light orange
KOH on Stipe Context: Orange in the mid-stipe, orange/brown by the base.

FeSO4 on Cap Skin: Dark olive.
FeSO4 on Stipe Skin: Dark olive.
FeSO4 on Pores: Slowly darkens to olive brown.
FeSO4 on Cap Context: Olive green
FeSO4 on Stipe Context: Olive green, getting darker as you move toward the base.

results.notes: Normally I wouldn’t spend much time trying to ID one of the zillion look-alike LBM’s; however, this one has some interesting features that I think might make an ID possible … for one of the MO pros, that is=) Three specimens were growing in a wood-chip mulch bed in suburban landscape. The largest cap: 2 cm., smooth, dry, with minutely serrated gills; KOH negative on cap. Stipe: off-center, longitudinally ridged, white above the ring zone, 3.5 cm. X 3 mm. at apex and 6 mm. at the impressively enlarged base; solid, white flesh, not discoloring or bruising when sliced. At first I thought maybe a Cortinarius because of the enlarged base and the whispy “threads” seen on the cap (remnants of a veil?), but I did NOT get a rusty-brown spore print. The print was creamy-white. I considered that the serrated gills might be just ragged gills due to age, but these mushrooms were not more than a day old; I had checked this mulch bed the day before. So, because of the off-center stipes, the serrated gills, and the creamy-white spore print, I’m going with Lentinellus, but not very confidently. Hoping someone recognizes this interesting little mushroom and can re-direct my approach to teasing out this identification.

results.notes:
Last updated/edited on 25-Jan-18:
> This single specimen was collected by Stef Bierman and Paul Patterson in oak and pine woods during the NJMA club foray.
> The gross morphology can be inferred from the pictures. The colors in the pix are accurate.
> The cap is 5 cm in diameter and 2.5 cm thick in the center. The pore surface stains deep blue upon injury. The tube layer is 5.5 mm thick at the widest point. The stipe is 8.5 cm long and 2 cm wide at the apex and 2.5 cm wide at the bottom. The odor of the exposed context is earthy-fungal, fairly pleasant. The taste was not recorded (not tasted).
> Macro-chemical Tests: KOH = bright rusty orange on pileipellis; deep orange on context. NH3 = dingy yellow on pileipellis; dark yellow on context, resolving to background flesh color. FeSO4 = negative on cap or merely intensifying the background color; negative to grayish on context.

DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion:
> A clean and contiguous 2160 bps nrITS-LSU sequence was obtained from this collection. There are no ambiguous characters.
> The 717 bps nrITS portion matched several trusted accessions of Xerecomus sclerotiorum recently posted to GenBank. All the other BLAST hits were irrelevant due to the low similarity (<96%).
> Not surprisingly, a BLAST search of the 1443 bps full-length nrLSU sequence returned no meaningful hits.
> Next, a search of the first 978 characters (through to and including LR5 primer) painted an interesting but confusing picture. After sorting the list by % identity, the most similar hit, at 98.3%, is Pulchroboletus rubricitrinus, a North American bolete. The next three hits (average of 98.1%) are 3 accessions of Puchroboletus roseoalbidus, an Old World taxon. The genus Pulchroboletus is a member of the subfamily Xerocomoideae as per the phylogenetic studies of Boletaceae by Wu et al. (2014 & 2016). Directly below that are many accessions of members of Aureoboletus, Boletellus, and Xerocomus (97-98% range). These three genera also clade in Xerocomoideae, so placement of sclerotiorum into that subfamily based on this preliminary evidence is a possibility. However, also mixed in with these hits are accessions of boletes from different corners of the Boletaceae tree of life. Frustratingly, attempts at building GenBank cladograms utilizing various combinations of hits did little to sort things out. Perhaps none of this makes much sense because LSU alone lacks the requisite phylogenetic resolution in this tough case.
Morphologically, sclerotiorum, it being a red-and-yellow bluing bolete with a yellow boletoid hymenophore, doesn’t resemble taxa of North American Aureoboletus or Boletellus very much, but one can draw some morphological parallels with Pulchroboletus.
> Also, this sequence is 99.4% similar to the corresponding region in the matching nrLSU sequences of two morphologically related collections, obs 215764 (from NY) and obs 244588 (from VA). Thus, these three collections are likely to belong to the same genus, but the two taxa they represent are not conspecific (see below).
> Finally, a clean and contiguous 607 bps TEF-1-α sequence was also procured. There are no ambiguous characters. A BLAST search yielded the familiar complex and non-specific pattern of hits, and the similarity for these hits didn’t exceed ~93%. Comparison with the TEF-1-α sequence of 215764 clearly makes them discrete taxa, as the two traces are only 96.4% similar.
Conclusion: Based on the nrITS data, this collection is the true “Xerocomus” sclerotiorum. Gross morphology is also in line with this newly-described taxon. With regard to the provisional placement of sclerotiorum into Xerocomus, the authors do not disclose any supporting evidence in their new bolete book, BENA; however, in his personal communication to me, Prof. A. E. Bessette indicates his own molecular data warrants this tentative proposal. Nevertheless, the nrLSU and TEF-1-α data clearly imply that an alternate generic placement of this entity is necessary. Additional sequencing and rigorous phylogenetic analyses are required for transferring this taxon to its proper genus.
Also, X. sclerotiorum is genetically related to yet another underscribed taxon represented by obs 215764 (NY) & obs 244588 (VA), and, most recently, by obs 286328 (NJ), with its TEF-1-α sequence perfectly matching that of 215764.

results.notes:
Found by participants of the NJMA foray. Mostly hardwoods forest with some pine. It’s possible this was found in a swampy areas of the park.
Unfortunately, I neglected this collection for a while and by the time finally look at it, the fruiting bodies began to dry.
The color of fresh cuticle is tan to dull yellow. The cuticle peeled less than 1/3, but when this was tested, the cap context was getting dry. The color of fresh gills suggests the spores are yellow. The color of the drying gills is yellowish-gray. The stipe surface bruised gray upon injury. Sort of keyed out to R. claroflava, but that species is found mostly in New England and north of that growing in association with birch.

results.notes:
A single fruiting body collected by person(s) unknown at the NJMA foray and brought to my attention at the ID table.
The key morphological features of this bolete include:
(i) a medium brown pileipellis with some lighter brown-yellow areas
(ii) a light to medium orange pore surface bruising blue
(iii)) a pale to medium lemon-yellow stipe covered with brown punctate pattern and bruising dark blue
(iv) absence of yellow or red fuzz on stipe base
(v) a medium lemon-yellow context and tubes staining instantly dark violet-blue

Chemical Tests (see pix):
KOH = deep maroon on cap surface; medium to dark orange on context
NH3 = maroon on cap surface (lighter than the KOH reaction); deep yellow transitioning into medium light brown on context
FeSO4 = deep greenish-blue on cap surface; merely erasing the bluing on context

DNA Results and Discussion (original post from 25-Jun-19; updated on 4-Feb-20):
> A high quality, contiguous nrDNA sequence was obtained from this collection by Dr. Kudzma. The full-length nrITS sequence of 674 bps was derived from a single (reverse) read, whereas the first 978 characters of nrLSU are presumably a consensus product of two reads. There are no ambiguous characters in the entire nrDNA amplicon. The two sequences have been uploaded to this observation.
> A BLASTn of the ITS sequence returned 4 high-value hits in the 98.5-99.85% similarity range. Three of these accessions belong to the MO observations already sampled by Dr. Kudzma: obs 243925 (from PA), obs 264291 (from MO), and obs 294534 (from LA). The 4th hit is a GB accession derived from a FL voucher by other individuals. In addition to these, yet another MO collection of this taxon, obs 334881 from PA, has recently transpired, but it is yet to be accessioned into GenBank.
The next BLASTn hit by percent identity at 97.5% belongs to Sigrid Jakob’s collection from Arizona (https://www.inaturalist.org/observations/31878612). It’s definitely related to this eastern critter; however, I have reservations about it being conspecific, provided that its ITS sequence has been properly edited, particularly at the 5’ and 3’ ends, where most mismatches take place. A number of AZ boletes tested by Terri Clements showed close genetic affinities to several eastern taxa. While their ITS sequences are sufficiently different to suggest discrete entities, conspecificity cannot ruled out at this point without testing additional loci.
> A MUSCLE alignment of all the 6 ITS sequences (see the uploaded file) identifies no fewer than 18 positions featuring single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) events that represent a range of natural variation seen in the genetic make-up of what appears to be a single species distributed across a wide geographical range. This intraspecific variability is to be expected, as we are likely dealing with isolated populations of this bolete. However, 2/3 of these mismatches involve ambiguous characters – i.e., the presence of two possible bases at a specific position in the same organism – in just 1 or 2 out of 6 sequences per each site. This means that these differences are of little import, and only a few remaining shared SNP sites matter. A summary of this information is condensed in the table below. The base numbering shown is from the very first nucleotide of ITS; the observed ambiguities are “M” (A/C), “R” (purines A/G), and “Y” (pyrimidines C/T); “?” indicates unknown bases due to incomplete sequences; “—” indicates a gap.

002 026 119 148 391 414 421 430 505 512 542 568 592 593 606 622 627 648
MO294534 (LA) ? G T T T T A C T G T C T C T T G T
FLAS-F-60878 (FL) T G C ― T T A C T G C C T C C T A ?
MO243925 (PA) T G C ― T T A C T C T C T C C T A C
MO243999 (NJ) T G C ― T T A C T G T C T C C T A C
MO264291 (MO) Y R C ― C Y R C Y G T Y Y M C Y G C
MO334881 (PA) ? ? C ― Y Y R Y T G T C T M C T G C

As explained above, the following SNP sites are NOT true mismatches: nos. 2, 26 in ITS1 and 414, 421, 430, 505, 568, 592, 593, and 622 in ITS2. Also, #148 in ITS1 is NOT a real mismatch because at this point in all sequences there are several "T"s in a row (= single base repeat = homopolymeric stretch), and the Louisiana exemplar just has an extra thymine. Lastly, #391, which happens to be at the very end of the highly conserved 5.8S sublocus, is what I call a fully polymorphic site. Featuring pyrimidines, one sequence has a “C”, while four have a “T”, and the remaining one has both of these nucleotides present (“Y”).
The real mismatches fall into several kinds:
1) Pyrimidines in #119, #606 and #648 = “T” in the Louisiana collection vs “C” in all others
2) Pyrimidines in #542 = “C” in the Florida collection vs “T” in all others.
3) No. 512 = “C” in Dave W’s PA voucher vs “G” elsewhere is an unusual and the most distinct one of all, as the bases are not from the same chemical class
4) Purines in #627 = “A” appears three times and so does “G”. Technically a mismatch, it’s likely not because the equal frequency of appearance for each of the purines. I am pretty certain that eventually someone will come across a specimen that has “R” here, which will make this site fully polymorphic, just like #391.
> An ITS pholygenetic tree, derived from the BLASTn of obs 334881, was built in GenBank and uploaded to this observation. It shows hypothetical relationships between several North American and European taxa of Neoboletus. The take home message is that each group/cluster in the tree represents a species. Note the AZ collection separating away from the 5 eastern vouchers to be a species in its own right. The MO & PA collections are clustering on a separate sub-branch because they have more ambiguities/SNPs than the others.

> The SNP situation in the LSU locus is not as evolved, but, nevertheless, there are 6 positions showing such variations in the five derived sequences (the FL voucher apparently hasn’t been sampled for LSU). Four of these are “fake mismatches” involving single ambiguous characters vs a specific base. The second PA voucher, MO334881 is responsible for 3/4 of such cases. The details are summarized below, and will not be discussed further as the reader should be well-versed in this subject by now.

130 162 185 442 450 577
MO334881 (PA) T Y T G Y R
MO264291 (MO) Y C T G T G
MO294534 (LA) T C T G T G
MO243999 (NJ) T C C A T G
MO243925 (PA) T C T A T G

I am proposing Neoboletus brunneosquamulosus Safonov & Kudzma nom. prov. for this distinct NA taxon and phylogenetic OTU. The epithet refers to the coating of visible brown squamules on the stipe, which appears to be a fairly constant trait overall even though its presentation varies from one collection to the other (the LA voucher is heavily squamulose).

results.notes:
> Growing on a steep hill under beech and oak trees.
> My best guess this is something in the X. subtomentosus group.
> Overall this mushroom was “painted” in brown tones, even the pore surface, and from a distance it looked like a Porphyrellus sp.
> The pores didn’t stain blue when bruised and neither did the exposed pale yellow context.
> The ammonia test on cap gave a complex picture. I think there was a instant flash of very dark green-blue. The cap cuticle under the reagent turned mahogany red, then deep rusty orange; the blotted surface was dingy yellow. There was a persistent deep blue halo around the reagent drop, eventually resolving green.

DNA Results and Discussion (originally posted Feb-1-2017; edited 1-Jul-2020 & 22-Dec-20):
> A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence of 948 bps was derived from this material by Dr. Kudzma. It consists of the last 17 characters of nrSSU, followed by the full-length nrITS sequence of 786 bps and then by the first 145 base pairs of nrLSU.
> A GenBank BLASTn-100 search of the full-length nrITS sequence gave an almost perfect match with ‘Boletus subtomentosus voucher F:PRL5774MAN’ (accession #GQ166882) collected from Bailly Cemetery in Indiana Dunes State Park, IN: 785/786 = 99.9% similarity, no gaps, 100% query cover. The majority of hits featured, by and large, sequences of various Xerocomus species with pairwise similarity in the 84-93% range, query covers of only 45-73%, and E values >0. Gaps comprised close to 50% of mismatching events.
> Based on the BLASTn profile, MO244111 likely represents an undescribed North American Xerocomus species. DNA appears to support what the morphology already conveyed to the eye; however, without sampling other loci and building phylogenetic trees, this preliminary inference should be treated with plenty of caution. The bolete voucher collected in Indiana is undoubtedly the same species. The name X. subtomentosus obviously doesn’t apply to this entity as the former bolete is a well known and extensively studied European taxon that happens to be the type species of the genus Xerocomus sensu stricto, with numerous nrITS sequences posted to GenBank.

results.notes:
In mowed grass beneath oaks, mushroomy odor, taste bitter
Cap brown, margin light with light yellow or buff spores at first glance; spore print very thin but indicates dark green-brown spores. Very narrow sterile band at margin. Pores olivaceous quickly staining dark brown-black, recessed at stipe. Stipe white, tapered downward, turning very finely punctate red /pink at base.
Context of cap and stipe pale olivaceous /drab white, quickly turning dark brown in KOH, pale gray with some yellow slowly becoming gray in FeSO4, no reaction then brown in NaOH. Base of stipe staining dark red fading to purple then dull purple when cut.

results.notes:
This is from the same patch that produced observation 242587, which people considered to be “bicolor”. I’m eager to compare it to the other group I picked today (observation 244233) because that is the “ur” bicolor I originally learned and it seems very different from these.

Found in grass and moss between oaks. It’s been quite dry but I found a lot of boletes around the park nevertheless. It seems that they’re pushing out now despite the dryness, but about 3 weeks later. This ground was merely dry but not baked hard. North Park by the Round Top shelter.

Mycelium was white. The red on the cap and stipe was a pure, dark red with no hint of pink or orange. The cap got more brown/tan with age (there were several specimens), and the oldest ones had a good deal of cracking on the surface but no actual fissuring.

Cap flesh was white to pale yellow, but the stem flesh was yellow (with red larval tunnels). These colors were distinctly different, but a little less so than observed with the earlier observation. The mushroom had no distinctive smell or flavor (maybe – maybe – a lingering “metallic” taste). The context was a little stickier than I’m used to.

Very thin pore layer was yellow and bruised very slowly. Only the oldest ones bruised blue/black. Younger specimens bruised more brown, and some not at all. This is also a distinct difference from the earlier observation.

The largest specimen was fully mature but not yet old. It measured as follows:

HEIGHT: 5 cm
CAP WIDTH: 7.5 cm
CONTEXT: 15 mm (1.5 cm)
TUBES: >2 mm (maybe 2-¼?)

I also measured a younger one:

HEIGHT: 4.5 cm
CAP WIDTH: 4.2 cm
CONTEXT: 14 mm
TUBES: 2 mm even

This pattern was consistent across the other 30 or so specimens I found. By way of analogy, they seem to poke the umbrella out of the ground and then spread it when nearing full growth. Older ones are just a little taller, but much wider. The tube layer does not change its depth significantly.

White mycelium. Stem red all the way up until right near the pores, where it became very yellow. No reticulation. All stems were pillar shaped with the exception of a vague bulge at the bottom for some of the true babies. This is a very marked contrast to the other bicolor collection today. Those were very clavate, or even bulbous. They were also several times larger than these and had a much, much thinner tube layer (well under 1 mm).

AMMONIA The reactions were slightly stronger across the board than seen in observation 242587, and in some cases slightly different. All in all I conclude that ammonia is an unreliable test chemical for this species.

Ammonia on Cap Skin: No reaction, or possibly a little orange. (observation 242587 was no reaction or maybe a little yellow with red toward the center.)
Ammonia on Stipe Skin: Yellow. (observation 242587 was maybe a little yellow with red toward the center.)
Ammonia on Pores: Yellow, the strongest reaction. (observation 242587 was no reaction, or possibly a little darker yellow.)
Ammonia on Cap Context: Yellow. (observation 242587 was no reaction.)
Ammonia on Stipe Context: Slightly darker yellow. (observation 242587 was no reaction.)

KOH The reactions were similar across the board to observation 242587. This species seems to reliably turn orange or orange red when hit with KOH, with the strongest reaction on the pores and the weakest on the cap context.

KOH on Cap Skin: Orange. (observation 242587 was yellow orange. Note that Baorangia bicolor is supposed to have no reaction).
KOH on Stipe Skin: Orange. (observation 242587 was yellow orange.)
KOH on Pores: Obvious orange. (observation 242587 was obvious red/orange.)
KOH on Cap Context: Orange, but faint. (observation 242587 was no reaction.) In both cases the KOH ate away a hole.
KOH on Stipe Context: Orange. (observation 242587 was light orange.)

IRON SALTS Note that I’m now using FeCl instead of FeSO4. The reactions were basically identical across the board. This species turns olive or olive-green with the application of iron salts. The cap context seems to react a little less than the more yellow stipe context.

FeCl3 on Cap Skin: Olive green. (observation 242587 was olive)
FeCl3 on Stipe Skin: Olive green. (observation 242587 was olive)
FeCl3 on Pores: Olive green. (observation 242587 was olive brown, with a slower reaction).
FeCl3 on Cap Context: Olive green. (observation 242587 was also olive green)
FeCl3 on Stipe Context: Olive green. (observation 242587 was also olive green). In both observations the reaction was a little stronger in the yellower stipe flesh than it was in the paler cap context.

results.notes:
These were found about ½ mile away from observation 244232, at the Deer Browse 2 shelter rather than the Round Top shelter. Both have been regularly identified as “bicolors” but I do not think they are the same species. The red on these is just a little pinker, the stems are uniformly clavate/bulbous, the flesh is much denser, and they react to the dryness with caps that fissure rather than just growing pale. In addition, the tube layers on those were thin (around 2 mm) but the tubes on these are vanishingly tiny (around ¾ mm) even though these are physically larger. To be fair, the chemical tests yielded almost identical results and I leave open the possibility that this patch simply produces vastly larger versions of the same mushroom, which I have only gotten to see in baby form.

Note the similarities to observation 243105, which was found several miles away at Hartwood Acres.

Found in grass and moss between oaks. It’s been quite dry but I found a lot of boletes around the park nevertheless. It seems that they’re pushing out now despite the dryness, but about 3 weeks later. This ground was merely dry but not baked hard. North Park by the Round Top shelter.

NOTE: I have roped off a few specimens in order to document their growth. No one has ever seen a fully mature mushroom from this patch because they get mowed so often. Many thanks to the North Park authorities for cooperating. I will try to update the observation with daily photos.

Mycelium was white. The red on the cap and stipe was a pure, bright red with occasional pink shadings but no orange. The cap got more yellow tan with age and fissured in a very pronounced way from the heat and dry.

Cap flesh was yellow, and the stem flesh was a pronounced yellow (with red larval tunnels). In some specimens the difference was hard to see. The mushroom had no distinctive smell or flavor. The texture was … wonderful. This is one of those intensely desirable mushrooms that fills your inner chef with greed. I know from experience that they cook up slimy when fresh, but they dry wonderfully and are ideal when used in that format. Perhaps half the flavor of a true edulis (which is pretty high on my personal scale).

The pores did not bruise at all. The tube layer is fabulously thin, no more than ¾ mm on even the largest specimen (all are young and have unopened pores). The measurements from the largest specimen were:

HEIGHT: 7 cm
CAP WIDTH: 8 cm
CONTEXT: 19 mm (almost 2 cm)
TUBES: <1 mm (maybe ¾ mm?)

White mycelium. Stem red all the way up until right near the pores, where it became very yellow. No reticulation. All stems were heavily bulged – clavate to almost bulbous. This is a very marked contrast to the other bicolor collection today (observation 244232), which have much smaller stems by proportion and are uniformly pillar-shaped.

AMMONIA The reactions were weak across the board.

Ammonia on Cap Skin: No reaction
Ammonia on Stipe Skin: No reaction, or maybe a little brown
Ammonia on Pores: No reaction, or possibly a little darker yellow.
Ammonia on Cap Context: No reaction, or possibly a little darker yellow.
Ammonia on Stipe Context: Brown

KOH on Cap Skin: Orange.
KOH on Stipe Skin: Orange Red.
KOH on Pores: Orange.
KOH on Cap Context: Orange, but faint.
KOH on Stipe Context: Orange-red, and very distinct.

FeCl3 on Cap Skin: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Stipe Skin: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Pores: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Cap Context: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Stipe Context: Olive green.

results.notes: I admit, these were not in prime condition when I found them, and I’m not sure about the identity. However this is the first of this variety that I’ve been able to find in this region (which I thought was quite exciting). I believe it’s a bolete of some kind. The cap is super sponge like and retains water really well (discovered this when I washed them). It also has this interesting bright yellow pigment all over it (spores maybe, not sure?). It has a strong mushroomy aroma, not quite the same as a button mushroom but similar. I picked several of these (although most were already rotten), and I don’t how the stem on a fresh one holds up but the stem on these practically fell out in my hand – very soft connection there between stem and cap. The stem is about 1.5 inch, cap about 2.25 inches. Also, if you look closely, you’ll see how some debris looks like it’s been superficially ingested by the flesh of the mushroom. Interesting. Anyway, sorry it’s not a ideal specimen but I had to post because this variety has been tough to come by around here, and it was a true pleasure to find these (rotten or not). Thank you.
results.location_name: Jackson Co., Kansas City, Missouri, USA

results.notes: I admit, these were not in prime condition when I found them, and I’m not sure about the identity. The cap is super sponge like and retains water really well (discovered this when I washed them). It also has this interesting bright yellow pigment all over the underside of the cap (spores maybe, not sure?). The top of the cap has this gorgeous mixture of reds, golds, ochres and a smidge of violet. It has a strong mushroomy aroma, not quite the same as a button mushroom but similar. I picked several of these (although most were already rotten), and I don’t how the stem on a fresh one holds up but the stem on these practically fell out in my hand – very soft connection there between stem and cap. The stem is about 1.5 inch, cap about 3 inches. Also, if you look closely, you’ll see how some debris looks like it’s been superficially ingested by the flesh of the mushroom. Interesting. Anyway, sorry it’s not a ideal specimen but I had to post because this variety has been tough to come by around here, and it was a true pleasure to find these (rotten or not). Thank you.

results.notes: I’m always happy to find a fresh batch of these, especially when they’re not even a block from my house! These were super fresh and growing on the usual freshly fallen tree branch, located in this small urban patch of flora (which I frequent regularly). Common name: Wood ear, Tree ear or Judas’ ear. Very rubbery to the touch (not as fragile as a cup mushroom). The skin has this fantastic translucent quality, very elegant and a blast to photograph! Any objections out there regarding the edibility? If my identification is correct, then I’ve read these are common in Asia. I’ve posted before, but just to reiterate, these are known to fight against blood coagulation in the arteries (which is thought to explain why artery disease is so uncommon in Asia). Anyway, just a fun fact. Recipes anyone?
results.location_name: Jackson Co., Kansas City, Missouri, USA

results.notes:
Code: Bot_986/2016_DSC3646

Habitat: Fagus sylvatica forest with some Picea abies; moderately inclined slope at the foot of a mountain, northwest aspect; calcareous, skeletal forest ground; in shade; next to a river, humid air conditions; partly protected from direct rain by tree canopies; average precipitation ~ 3.000 mm/year, average temperature 7 – 9 deg C, elevation 525 m (1.720 feet), alpine phytogeographical region.

Substratum: almost totally rotten tree stump; probably Fagus sylvatica, possibly Picea abies.

Place: Lower Trenta valley, between villages Soča and Trenta, left bank of river Soča, upstream from Trenta 46 house, East Julian Alps, Posočje, Slovenia EC

Comment: Ceratiomyxa fruticulosa var. fruticulosa is one of the most distinctive and wide-spread myxomycetes (nowadays Protosteliomycetes). It is easy to recognize it since nothing similar exists outside tropical regions. Because of its bright white color, it is also easy to spot. Its genus name Ceratiomyxa comes from Greek words keras and myxa. The first means horn(s) and the second slime. And indeed it consists (in most cases) of many erects columns made of slimy substance. Unlike of all other myxomycetes the columns bear individual spores externally, on long stalks (see picture 2b, middle-left). However, it can appear also in a much different form, which is treated by some authors as separate species Ceratiomyxa poroides Alb. & Schwein or a subspecies of Ceratiomyxa fruticulosa. Then it looks like spongy, poroid or effused crust, much similar to some poroid basidiomycetes. The plasmodium of Ceratiomyxa fruticulosa is watery translucent (see picture 2a, slime among developed columns). It initially forms whitish blobs (see picture 1b, upper part), which in mature stage develop into simple or sparsely branched columns covered by stalked, white spores looking similar to glandular hairs of higher plants.

Nikon D700/Nikkor Micro 105mm/f2.8 and Canon G11, 6.1-30mm/f2.8-4.5

results.notes:
I have never seen this Amanita before. It was going under Mt. Laurel, white pine and oak along the driveway (forested on either side).

Initially reminded me of Amanita onusta, but it is something else. The cap is tannish-gray, a quilt pattern like Russula crustosa, with roundish warts at center of cap. The are a combination of white and tan. The tan may be soil. There are short fragile white remnants of the universal veil on the cap edge. The white gills are free, crowded and shorter gills near the margin appear to be connected with the longer gills (similar to the Split Gill). The stipe is white, longer than the cap is wide, with a slightly enlarged base covered tightly with veil material. There is no ring.

results.notes:
These were found about 20 yards away from observation 244233, at the Deer Browse 3 shelter in gathered oak leaves. It’s been quite dry but these show up every year and it seems that they’re pushing out now despite the dryness, but about 3 weeks later. This ground was merely dry but not baked hard.

Mycelium was pale yellow rather than the white of observation 244233. The red on the cap and stipe was a pure, bright red with occasional pink shadings but no orange. The cap had a bit more yellow and tan, and not fissured at all, unlike observation 244233. There are some blue/green blotches on the stipe and cap, which is also different than observation 244233. Note that the blotches when the mushrooms were found and could not be reproduced by manual bruising. All stems were heavily bulged – clavate to almost bulbous. The same was true of observation 244233.

Cap flesh was off yellow, and the stem flesh was a pronounced yellow and very, very dense. There were no larval tunnels, which is also true of observation 244233. The mushrooms in this observation had an intense mushroomy smell that might be called “beefy” but that probably wouldn’t be the word a stranger would come up with if asked. The texture was just like observation 244233, with a wonderful, dense, intensely heft desirable mushrooms that fills your inner chef with greed. I know from experience that they cook up slimy when fresh, but they dry wonderfully and are ideal when used in that format. Perhaps half the flavor of a true edulis (which is pretty high on my personal scale).

When cut the stipe flesh very slowly (over a few minutes) develops a greenish stain that persists for 10-15 minutes before fading again. This was observed last year too, but in mushrooms that matched both the chemical tests and the description for B. pallidoroseus a lot more closely than these.

Note that the mushrooms dry to a brilliant, clear yellow almost the same as the darkest part of the fresh stipe. Photo attached.

The pores did not bruise at all. The tube layer is fabulously thin, no more than ¾ mm on even the largest specimen (all are young and have unopened pores). The measurements from the largest specimen were:

HEIGHT: 15 cm
CAP WIDTH: 7 cm
CONTEXT: 20 mm (2 cm)
TUBES: <1 mm (maybe ¾ mm?)

AMMONIA The reactions were weak across the board.

Ammonia on Cap Skin: No reaction
Ammonia on Stipe Skin: No reaction, or maybe a little brown
Ammonia on Pores: No reaction, or possibly a little darker yellow.
Ammonia on Cap Context: No reaction, or possibly a little darker yellow.
Ammonia on Stipe Context:No reaction, or possibly a little darker yellow, esp. lower down. Totally eliminated the greenish staining in the base area.

KOH on Cap Skin: Orange.
KOH on Stipe Skin: No reaction (a shocker!).
KOH on Pores: Orange.
KOH on Cap Context: Orange, but faint.
KOH on Stipe Context: Orange-red, and very distinct toward the bottom.

FeCl3 on Cap Skin: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Stipe Skin: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Pores: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Cap Context: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Stipe Context: Olive green.

results.notes:
Found in grass and moss between oaks. It’s been quite dry but our club walk found a lot of boletes nevertheless. This one stumped even JP3!

Mycelium was not obvious. The caps are dried-looking slate brown with darker brown regions and a few spots showing what might have been red under better circumstances. OTOH, we found a lot of boletes today where the native color had baked away and that could be the case here as well.

Cap flesh and stem flesh were both yellow, stained quickly, and then slowly faded. There was no real distinction between the color of the cap context and that of the stem. The mushroom had no distinctive smell or flavor. My wife commented that it had a distinctive lack of any odor!

The pores were very small even on these fully adult and mature specimens. The color was quite odd – a very clear orange above a very yellow ground color. Very thin pore layer was yellow and bruised very slowly. They readily bruised a dark blue/black.

The split specimen in the first picture (an average one) measured as follows:

HEIGHT: 7 cm
CAP WIDTH: 8.2 cm
CONTEXT: 13 mm (1.3 cm)
TUBES: 10 mm (1 cm)

In other words, almost half the cap was tubes. Texture was classic bolete, neither particularly spongy or firm.

No reticulation. All stems were pillar shaped.

AMMONIA Weak across the board, but rapidly eliminated the blue staining from the context in a very wide area.

Ammonia on Cap Skin: No reaction, or possibly a little orange.
Ammonia on Stipe Skin: No reaction, or possibly a little orange.
Ammonia on Pores: Possibly a little “burning” darker
Ammonia on Cap Context: No reaction of maybe a little yellow, but completely eliminated the blue staining in a wide area across the context even far away from the drop.
Ammonia on Stipe Context: Slightly darker as you moved down.

KOH Orange and red.

KOH on Cap Skin: Orange.
KOH on Stipe Skin: Orange.
KOH on Pores: Orange or red.
KOH on Cap Context: Orange, but faint.
KOH on Stipe Context: Darker Orange, and almost red by the base.

IRON SALTS Olive green and darker.

FeCl3 on Cap Skin: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Stipe Skin: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Pores: Olive leaning toward black.
FeCl3 on Cap Context: Olive yellow/green.
FeCl3 on Stipe Context: Olive greening the mid-stipe, and almost black by the base.

results.notes:
Found in grass and moss between oaks. It’s been quite dry but our club walk found a lot of boletes nevertheless. This one I recognize as common to the area, and almost certainly the same species described as “Boletus discolor” in observation 242270 and observation 242566.

John Plischke III made the same ID based on the orange/brown color at the edge of the cap. In his experience that is a distinctive characteristic of discolor. There are absolutely no hairs or other fuzz on the stipe that would tend to indicate subvelutipes. Everything stains like crazy, including the stipe. (The larger specimen in the main photo actually had a yellow stipe when found, but it darkened from handling alone).

We have had little or no rain for the past few weeks and the ground is very dry, but today’s club walk yielded several boletes nevertheless. These are young and in prime condition.

Cap flesh and stem flesh were both yellow and stained instantly. The stipe context might have blued a little less. The mushroom had no distinctive smell or flavor.

The pores were tiny, but these are all young. Tubes were about 1/6 as deep as the cap context was tall – 3 mm compared to 17. The pores bruised as instantly and profoundly as the rest, if not more so.

The split specimen in the first picture measured as follows:

HEIGHT: 5 cm
CAP WIDTH: 4.7 cm
STEM WIDTH: 2.5 cm
CONTEXT: 17 mm (1.7 cm)
TUBES: 3 mm

Texture was classic bolete, neither particularly spongy or firm. No reticulation or other marks on the stem at all, other than bruising. All stems were vaguely clavate.

Ammonia on Cap Skin: No reaction or possibly a different brown (browning as on the stipe would not have been visible).
Ammonia on Stipe Skin: Brown
Ammonia on Pores: No reaction or red, BUT left a pale ring around the drop.
Ammonia on Cap Context: Reddish brown AND eliminated the staining in a wide area.
Ammonia on Stipe Context:Reddish brown AND eliminated the staining in a wide area. Not darker than the cap context.

KOH on Cap Skin: No reaction (but maybe hidden by the original cap color)
KOH on Stipe Skin: Brownish orange
KOH on Pores: Orange or red.
KOH on Cap Context: Red, with a thin ring of no blue staining.
KOH on Stipe Context: Orange or red, with a thin ring of no blue staining.

IRON SALTS Olive green and darker.

FeCl3 on Cap Skin: Olive dark (cap color makes any change hard to see)
FeCl3 on Stipe Skin: Olive green.
FeCl3 on Pores: Olive leaning toward black.
FeCl3 on Cap Context: Olive yellow/green.
FeCl3 on Stipe Context: Olive yellow/green.

results.notes:
I was pleased with myself about this one. The cap is a little red for ferruginous (f/k/a Boletus spadiceus in three varieties) but the books say that it can shade toward either the red/pink side or the yellow/tan side. The rest seems to be a clear match.

The very thick tubes end in yellow pores that stain green on their own and a darker blue/green when bruised. There is a thin red line in the creamy white/yellow cap flesh right next to the skin (arguably red dragged from the skin, I admit). The larval tunnels are pinkish/reddish.

And most of all, there is ridging on the stipe by the top, though that’s hard to see in these photos.

Needless to say, the chemical reactions don’t match up. Particularly my ammonia, which was supposed to cause a greenish flash ) before turning reddish brown (sometimes grayer). I got no reaction at all. But c’est la vie. The darned thing was awfully dry.

A single fruiting body growing along the Yellow Trail running along the creek (west of the Pavilion & Amphitheater).
Exposed context turned pale pinkish brown. Flesh mild and slightly astringent. KOH on cap cuticle is blackish-maroon (in line with NAB).

DNA sequencing & results (posted 18-Feb-19):
> A clean and contiguous nrLSU sequence consisting of the first 984 bps (through to and ending in the LR5 primer) was obtained by Dr. Kudzma from this material. There are 2 ambiguous characters in this stretch of the locus; both are a “Y” (C/T).
> A BLASTn of this sequence closely matched two GenBank accessions of T. variobrunneus, KF030315 & KF030316. Also, alignment of this sequences with that of another suspected variobrunneus collection of mine, obs 281620, showed them to be very similar. Furthermore, Geoff Balme’s mysterious obs 287518 also appears to be this taxon based on the nrLSU data (vide infra).
> Below is the alignment analysis of the 5 LSU sequences. There are a total of 8 mismatching and/or ambiguous positions (single nucleotide polymorphisms); other than that, all the sequences are perfectly identical. Character “M” seen in MO287518 corresponds to A/C. SNP sites 243, 448, and 758 can be considered “fully polymorphic” because they feature all possible combinations of a substitution series; for example site 243 has a resolved “A” in two sequences, a resolved “G” in one, and “A/G” in the remaining two.
Note that GenBank’s KF030316 doesn’t have any ambiguous characters. This single haplotype is present only in MO244395, which in addition to it has three other haplotypes at positions 512 & 570, i.e., combinations C & T, T & C, and T & T.
…………………..243….448….483….512….570….692….720….758
MO244395……A……..T………T……..Y……..Y………C……..C……….A
MO281620……R……..C………C…….C……..C………C……..Y……….R
MO287518……G……..Y………C…….C……..C………M…….Y………..G
KF030315…….R……..Y………Y…….C……..C………C……..C………..G
KF030316…….A……..T………T…….C……..C………C……..C………..A

results.notes:
A single fruiting body growing under red oaks. Cap is pale grayish tan. Stipe is concolorous. White reticulation at the apex gradually becoming brown toward the bottom. White unchanging context. Pleasant fungal odor.
Half of this collection was transferred to Dr. B.T.M. Dentinger at UMNH in March 2018.

DNA Results:
Originally, the ITS locus was requested for this collection. Unfortunately, as Dr. Kudzma discovered, it suffers from severe heterogeneity/polymorphism, and obtaining a meaningful sequence of the “proposed barcode marker” was not possible.
However, since the reverse read starts from the LR22 primer (in the 3’—>5’ direction), we fortuitously have the first well-resolved 320 bps of nrLSU. An annotated phylogram derived from the BLASTn of this sequence fragment is uploaded to this observation.
This taxon, even if it already has a name, clearly falls outside of the current scope of “variipes group” and instead clades near the oak-loving European B. reticulatus. While the identity of B. reticulatus is beyond doubt, we still don’t know exactly what phylogenetic entity constitutes B. variipes. We’ll find out once Peck’s type is barcoded.
Also, I think this taxon happens to be the same mushroom discussed by M. Kuo: https://www.mushroomexpert.com/boletus_cf_reticulatus.html.
Based on my assessment of the available information, the current range of this lovely “summer porcini” is from ME south to NC and west to IN.

Amanita flavescens, Amanitaceae, Agaricales.
Yellow grisette, поплавок жёлтый или толкачик.
Light-yellow fragile mushroom.
Cap: 4-10cm, bell-shaped, smooth, convex up to flat, sometimes with a small central knob, margin radially grooved, because skin is transparent (colour changed from yellow up to yellowish-white, sometimes brownish-yellow for dried unit). Young cap shape between oval and cone and it often has remnant of veil at the top.
Flesh is white.
Gills: free, close to almost distant, white up to dull yellow. Odour is weak and pleasant.
Stalk: 8-16cm long, whitish 0.6-3cm thick, enlarged weakly down. Lower part of stalk has a sag-like veil. Partial veil is loose and rare.
Habitat: small group scattered in pine-tree forest with rare birches in dry places or along edge in meadows. Mushroom is edible as light-brown and light-gray kinds.
Season: June-September.

results.notes:
> Two fruiting bodies growing next to each other in mixed deciduous woods; the surrounding trees are maples and a single hickory, with oaks ~15-20 yards away. I’ve been visiting this spot for over a decade, but have never seen these boletes there before.
> The colors are presented accurately in the pix. Interestingly, the older fb had a richer, brighter pileipellis color than the younger one. The pore surface is dingy yellow to greenish-yellow in the older fb over time. The pore surface of the older fruitbody appeared to have bruised very faintly grayish-blue when fresh, resolving faint brownish. The stipe is light lemon-yellow, with some burgundy at the base and where the slug damage occurred in the large fb. Other than that, there is absolute no hint of red in the stipe. There is no bluing on the stipe surface upon handling or injury. The exposed context is whitish to pale yellow in the cap context and light yellow in the stipe, appears to be unchanging in the first 10-15 min. However, a narrow band of very faint and diffuse bluing was observed directly above the tubes only, resolving to faint grayish and then back to the original context color.
Large fb: Cap = 12-13.5 cm wide and up to 2 cm thick; tube layer = up to 1 cm thick; stipe = 6.5 cm long and uniformly 2.5 cm wide.
Small fb: cap = 3.8 cm wide and up to 1 cm thick; tube layer = 2.5 mm thick; stipe = 6.2 cm long and uniformly 1.2-1.4 cm wide.
Chemical Tests (performed on the small fb, unless stated otherwise): KOH = mustard yellow on pileipellis; pale orangish on context; brownish on tubes (larger fb only). NH4OH = mustard yellow on piliepillis (a bit paler than KOH); no reaction on context. FeSO4 = medium brown, resolving bluish on pileipellis; pale slate on context.

DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (last updated on 20-Feb-20):
> A clean and contiguous nrDNA sequence was obtained by Dr. Kudzma from this material. The full-length nrITS region in this species/organism is 707 bps long (ITS1= 225 bps, 5.8S = 161 bps and ITS2 = 321 bps). There are 3 ambiguities — 2 x “R” and a “Y”. The nrLSU sequence consists of the first 1441 bps of the locus. No ambiguities were detected in this sequence.
A BLASTn search of the first 978 characters (the most commonly sequenced region) returned a hit list consisting of taxa from different corners of the Boletaceae and lacking hints of a phylogenetic structure. At its face value, this result is consistent with the overall morphological profile of this bolete, though to the inexperienced eye roodyi may look similar to members of such genera as Baorangia, Lanmaoa and Pulchroboletus. Sequence similarity didn’t exceed 97% with even for the top-scoring hits (Pulchroboletus sclerotiorum). Attempted tree-building in GenBank met with failure due to a confused topology and a strange selection of the outgroup by the program, meaning that other loci would be required for establishing a meaningful phylogenetic inference. However, there were indications that B. roodyi could clade in the subfamily Xerocomoideae. Indeed, this notion was confirmed by phylogenies derived later from a TEF-1 sequence (see below).
> The TEF-1 sequence is 930 base pairs long. The sequenced region is between the EF1-983F and EFgr primers, which were seen but edited out. There are a total of 6 miscellaneous ambiguities present in this stretch of the gene.
Extensive experimentation with phylogenetic trees built in GenBank from the relevant BLASTn hits strongly indicates that B. roodyi is a member of Xerocomoideae. Since inclusion of accessions from other Boletaceae families intermixing with those of Xerocomoideae don’t alter this placement and only complicate the overall picture, the final phylograms focus solely on the representatives of Xerocomoideae.
Fig.1 was built in GenBank from a BLASTn of the first 583 characters of the sequence (the most commonly sequenced region of TEF-1), whereas Fig.2 – derived from a BLASTn of the entire sequence – was generated in www.phylogeny.fr in the “one click” mode.1 In the latter, unrooted tree, B. roodyi (yellow highlight) is placed with moderate support next to Pulchroboletus and Boletellus. It appears that B. roodyi and B. miniato-olivaceus (blue highlight) could represent two distinct monotypic genera. The overall morphological gestalt of these taxa is in line with this phylogenetic inference.
Reference:
1 http://www.phylogeny.fr/documentation.cgi#oneclick

results.notes:
One final example of WCSP’s “subvelutipes group”. Note the pale yellow stipes devoid of any red streaks or dotted patterns seen in all but one of the posted examples from this park and pale orange pore surface despite the young age. Stipe base is burgundy, as usual. Identical chemical tests to those observed previously — see obs 244417 for details.

Spore Measurements (9-Feb-18):
[40/1/1]; L x W = (11.6-) 12.1~14.9 (-15.1) x 4.7~5.6 μm; L x W = 13.2 × 5.1 μm; Q = (2.17-) 2.29-2.78 (-2.80); Q = 2.60.
Smooth, brownish-yellow, sometimes with a reddish-brown “aura” around large, greenish oil droplets, mono-gutulate to multi-gutulate, subfusoid-subventricose to decidedly ventricose and somewhat inequlateral to inequilateral in side/profile-view (dorsi-ventral) with a fairly pronounced suprahilar plage.
These measurements, including the Q & Qav values, are in excellent agreement with those of obs 170841. This makes perfect sense, as two collections are conspecific. This is because even though 170841 has not been sequenced, it grew in exactly the same spot as obs 243052, and that one has its nrLSU & TEF-1 sequences matching those of 244427.

DNA Sequencing Results (last updated 21-Jan-19):
> A clean and contiguous nrLSU sequence of 1260 bps was obtained from this material by Dr. Kudzma. Unfortunately, the first 184 nucleotides from the 5’ end had to be edited out for quality control. The missing region includes the LR0R, ITS4 and ITS6R primers that together account for 69 nucleotides. There are no ambiguous characters, it’s a single haplotype.
This sequence is a 100% match to the overlapping/aligned regions in the LSUs of obs 206608, obs 212359, obs 243052, obs 251141, and obs 287453. Of these only 243052 comes from the same park – it was growing ~100 yards from 244427 in the same uninterrupted oak-hickory-beech-maple woods. These two collections share the all-yellow furfuraceous stipe and pale orange pores with a pronounced yellow rim.
> A clean and contiguous TEF-1-alpha sequence of 607 bps was also procured by Dr. Kudzma. The sequenced region is between and including the EF1-983 and EF-1567R primers. There are 3 ambiguous characters; all three are a “Y” (C/T).
Careful comparison of this TEF-1-α sequence with those of obs 206608, obs 212359, obs 243052, obs 251141, and obs 288090 shows that the sequences are essentially identical. The differences are present as a small and variable number of single nucleotide polymorphism (SNP) events at 7 specific positions shared between these organisms. Below is a summary of all numbered hetero-sites for these 6 collections (“R” = A & G; “Y” = C & T); the base count in this alignment starts from the 1st character of the EF1-983F primer:
………………….30…..108…..422…..443…..489…..590…..599
206608………Y………C……….R………..Y………G………C……….C
243052………T………C……….G…….…C………G………C….…….C
244427………Y………C……….A……….Y………G……….Y…….…C
251141………Y………C……….A……….T………G……….C….……C
212358………Y………C……….R……….Y………R….……C.………C
288090………Y………Y……….R……….Y………G…….…C.………Y
As can be seen from the above table, only 243052 is represented by a single TEF-1-α haplotype (no ambiguities), while 251141 with a single “Y” has two, 206608 & 24427 have eight, 212358 has sixteen, and 288090 (with 5 SNPs) has up to 32 haplotypes in the sequenced stretch of the gene. Since the observed ambiguity profiles for positions 422 and 443 are unique, not a single haplotype variant is shared by all collections. For example, the single haplotype of 243052 is present only in 206608, 212358 and 288090.
Discussion (last updated 20-Jan-19):
Based on the genetic data discussed above, this collection represents one of several existing phenotypic variants (morphotypes) of the most common and widespread hardwood-associated red-pored bolete species found in eastern North America. The extreme morphological variability observed in this species can be readily appreciated from the images of the other 5 sequenced collections.
For further information on this taxon, such as phylogenetic trees, see the notes in obs 206608.

results.notes:
Collected at the NJMA group foray.
The cap surface is very corrugated and pitted. The cap disc is practically black (looks dark violet-brown because of the flash?) with splashes of orange-yellow on the periphery. The dingy yellow pores bruise brown; the tubes are paler, yellowish-buff. The stipe surface is ornamented with a dense network of vertical ridges and groves extending from the apex to the base, and peppered with small dark brown scabers. The pale tan to pale yellow context stains brownish-red; the color intensifies gradually and peaks after a few minutes; the discoloration is restricted to the cap and the upper 1/3 of the stipe. KOH on flesh = medium orange. NH3 on flesh = first yellow, then dingy yellow, resolving bluish-gray.

DNA sequencing results and discussion:
> Originally, only the ITS “locus” of this collection was sequenced. Unfortunately, the sequence became non-specific midway through the ITS2 region. In the forward direction, 461 nucleotides were read without trouble before the sequence became heterogeneous. The reverse-direction read became non-specific after 224 bases. The non-specific region appears to be rather long, so the two fragment couldn’t be joined successfully to give a reliable contiguous sequence. However, the readable portions of the sequence consist of 680+ bases, a respectable length for an ITS sequence of a typical Boletaceae member (from the ITS1 primer to the start of LSU) in my experience. The shortest clean and contiguous ITS sequence I’ve seen so far belongs to Dave W’s striking-looking Boletaceae of obs 249345 (489 bps) and the longest one belongs to Leccinum variicolor of obs 256646 (1379 bps) due to numerous ITS1 mini-satellite insertions.
A GenBank BLAST search of the forward-read 461 bp sequence fragment did not return any matches or close hits; as a matter of fact, sequence similarity didn’t exceed 92%. When the hit list is sorted by maximum/total score, as opposed to by identity/similarity, 4 out of 10 the top-scoring hits are Leccinellum crocipodium vouchers from Europe; however, the % similarity of these 10 hits is in the 88-90% range, with lots of mismatching base-pairs and gaps.
> 17-Oct-17 update: A clean, contiguous 613 bps TEF-1-alpha sequence was obtained for this material. There are 4 ambiguous characters; all are a “Y”, corresponding to either of the pyrimidine bases C or T. A BLAST search of the sequence revealed no close or similar hits. As a matter of fact, the highest similarity didn’t exceed 95.9% even with exclusion of the ambiguous bases. The top two hits were Leccinellum crocipodium vouchers KT824054 and KF030434.
> The above results prove this bolete is not Leccinellum crocipodium or any other member of Leccinoideae, or Boletaceae for that matter, with ITS & TEF-1-alpha sequences posted to GenBank. However, this entity is indeed likely to belong in Leccinellum based on the morphological traits associated with this genus (e.g., yellow pores surface/tubes and prominently pitted/corrugated pileipellis).

Mushroom is edible as light-yellow and light-gray kinds.
Season: June-August.

results.notes:
This cryptic species was collected at the NJMA group foray. Unknown habitat (presumably deciduous woods). Cap color similar to Boletus nobilis. The stipe colors & texture are more in line with Xanthoconium affine. All pictures were taken 7-8 hrs post collection.
> The buff-tan cap is ~5 cm wide; the cap thickness is 6 mm at its widest point.
> The pore surface is pale buff at collection time and yellowish tan 30 hrs later after being stored in the fridge. Pores are round, 2 per mm.
> The tube layer is 3 mm thick at its widest point, medium yellow brown at maturity.
> The stipe is 6.7 cm long, 0.8 cm wide in the middle and 1.1 cm wide at the apex and base; yellowish at the apex apex, with brownish streaks below over a whitish background and with some areas of mostly white toward the base, not reticulate.
> The exposed context is white and unchanging both in cap and stipe.
> Chemical reactions were run 30 hrs post collection (the mushroom was stored at 38 F overnight):
KOH = deep yellow intensifying to medium orange-brown on cap surface; barely noticeable pink-magenta hue on cap context
NH3 = yellow on cap under the drop, with a pinkish-lilac “aura” due to ammonia vapors; pinkish-red on pore surface; barely noticeable pink-magenta hue on cap context
FeSO4 = olive-green on cap surface; negative to pale bluish on cap context

Half of this collection in the hands of Dr. B.T.M. Dentinger at UMNH as of March 2018.

results.notes:
On ground, under Sitka spruce. Mild tasting, non-acrid. No distinct odor.

Cap color variegated, from purplish to greenish, with greenish tones becoming more apparent in older specimens. Cuticle easily peeling to about half the radius of the cap.

Lamellae white in fresh specimens, becoming more orange brown as they sit at room temperature – this is a change in lamellar context color, not spore maturation, however. Lamellae brittle, not flexible.

Spore print very pale cream (Romagnesi IIa) (Only obtained after leaving a cap on paper for several days!)

Stipe surface white to purple-white, surface of base of stipe staining yellow when rubbed. Stipe surface strongly orange when exposed to ferrous sulfate granules, and yellow with KOH.

Context of cap and stipe white, not staining when cut.

Basidiospores russuloid, subglobose (occasionally globose) to broadly ellipsoid, small to medium warts (0.2-0.6 μm wide), with some connections but no reticulum; length: 5.9-7.3 μm (mean, stdev = 6.49 ± 0.49 μm), width: 5.0-6.3 μm (mean, stdev = 5.59 ± 0.38 μm), Q: (1.01) 1.08-1.30 μm (mean, stdev = 1.164 ± 0.097 μm).

Pileocystidia present, but distinct pileocystidia rare, and otherwise little differentiated from pileocystidia terminal hyphae.
